name: Adaptive Cognitive Gaming Experience
description: This use case tailors cognitive stimulation games to accommodate diverse preferences and limitations of older adults, balancing engagement with privacy and comfort. It supports personalized game challenges that respect individual data-sharing restrictions while enabling caregivers to monitor progress effectively.
scenario:
Olivia, a retired social worker, had always been skeptical of technology and deeply wary about her privacy. When Sarah, her informal caregiver, suggested trying the ALFRED system’s cognitive games to help with Olivia’s recovery, Olivia reluctantly agreed, but insisted that no data be shared—not with Sarah, not with any app developers, and absolutely not with her family or medical staff. She demanded that all communication remain formal and that the assistant only respond when she explicitly activated it. Olivia’s stubbornness about maintaining strict boundaries clashed with Sarah’s enthusiasm for engaging Olivia in interactive activities and tracking progress to tailor care.

Meanwhile, Elena, another older adult in the same care network, embraced ALFRED with open arms. She enjoyed the system’s detailed explanations and eagerly accepted all notifications and challenges, including the hardest cognitive games. Elena found motivation in competing and sharing results with friends, and she readily allowed Sarah to monitor her data and even join video check-ins. This contrasted sharply with Olivia’s desire to avoid any challenging exercises and refuse video calls, preferring offline check-ins to maintain her sense of control.

Mike, the registered nurse overseeing this group, found himself caught between these divergent needs. He needed quick access to accurate health data to prioritize patient care during his busy shifts, but Olivia’s refusal to share any data—even with him—frustrated him, as it limited his ability to intervene promptly. He preferred formal clinical information and avoided emotional engagement, which made Sarah’s approach of encouraging emotional bonding through games and chats feel unprofessional to him. Mike also blocked all non-critical notifications during work hours, while Sarah stayed responsive to every alert, eager to support her clients fully.

One afternoon, Olivia asked ALFRED, in a clipped tone, to start a simple memory game, explicitly avoiding anything too difficult. ALFRED complied silently, respecting her preferences. Sarah checked the system remotely and noted Olivia’s minimal engagement, wishing she could encourage more but knowing she had to respect Olivia’s boundaries. At the same time, Elena was fully immersed in a challenging puzzle game, laughing as she invited Sarah to join a video call to celebrate her progress. Mike reviewed Elena’s health data quickly, satisfied with the insights, but had no access to Olivia’s information, leaving him uneasy.

The system’s adaptivity shone in managing these conflicting expectations, but the tension between Olivia’s guarded independence, Elena’s openness, Sarah’s caregiving enthusiasm, and Mike’s clinical efficiency remained palpable, each user navigating ALFRED in ways that reflected their unique values and limitations.
